Metaphor.name: Metaphor
Metaphor.description: A figure of speech that makes a comparison between two unrelated things by stating one thing is another.
Metaphor.subject: noun

Simile.name: Simile
Simile.description: A figure of speech that compares two different things using the words 'like' or 'as'.
Simile.example: Her cheeks are red like a rose.
Simile.subject: noun

Alliteration.name: Alliteration
Alliteration.description: The repetition of the same consonant sounds at the beginning of words that are in close proximity.
Alliteration.example: Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers.
Alliteration.subject: adjective

Personification.name: Personification
Personification.description: A form of figurative language in which non-human objects are given human characteristics.
Personification.example: The wind whispered through the trees.
Personification.subject: noun

Onomatopoeia.name: Onomatopoeia
Onomatopoeia.description: A word that imitates the natural sounds of a thing. It creates a sound effect that mimics the thing described.
Onomatopoeia.subject: noun

Hyperbole.name: Hyperbole
Hyperbole.description: An exaggerated statement or claim not meant to be taken literally.
Hyperbole.example: I'm so hungry I could eat a horse.
Hyperbole.subject: pronoun

Irony.name: Irony
Irony.description: A contrast or incongruity between expectations for a situation and what is reality.
Irony.subject: noun

Oxymoron.name: Oxymoron
Oxymoron.description: A figure of speech in which two opposite ideas are joined to create an effect.
Oxymoron.subject: adjective

Anaphora.name: Anaphora
Anaphora.description: The deliberate repetition of the first part of the sentence in order to achieve an artistic effect.
Anaphora.example: Every day, every night, in every way, I am getting better and better.
Anaphora.subject: adverb

Euphemism.name: Euphemism
Euphemism.description: A polite, indirect expression that replaces words and phrases considered harsh and impolite, or which suggest something unpleasant.
Euphemism.subject: verb

Assonance.name: Assonance
Assonance.description: The repetition of vowel sounds in nearby words. It is used to reinforce the meanings of words or to set the mood.
Assonance.subject: noun

Consonance.name: Consonance
Consonance.description: The repetitive sounds produced by consonants within a sentence or phrase.
Consonance.example: The ship has sailed to the far off shores.
Consonance.subject: noun

Symbolism.name: Symbolism
Symbolism.description: The use of symbols to signify ideas and qualities, by giving them symbolic meanings that are different from their literal sense.
Symbolism.example: A chain can symbolize the coming together of two things.
Symbolism.subject: noun
